oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Association of Lameness in Dairy Cattle with Other Diseases
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Janssen, Dorothee
Guard, Charles L.
Warnick, Lorin
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lameness
problem herd
animal welfare
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lameness has been recognized as a frequently occurring disease syndrome in dairy cattle. The dimensions of the problem are immense. Consider that, according to Greenough and Vermunt,4 a herd should be considered a "problem herd" when the yearly incidence has surpassed 10%-while multiple studies show yearly incidences between 14% and 25% not to be uncommon.1,2,3,5 Not only is lameness a major animal welfare concern; its likely impact on productivity and development of concurrent diseases makes it an important economic factor. The results presented here propose to illuminate the correlation between lameness and other diseases in two large herds in New York state.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2001; 144
